questions.question_text: A network engineer is configuring a portal on Cisco ISE for employees. Employees must use this portal when registering personal devices with native supplicants. For onboarding devices connected with Cisco switches and Cisco wireless LAN controllers, the internal CA must be used. Which portal type must the engineer configure?

comments.content: Your explanation tell us that the answer is C because the, question says "native supplicants" regards

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Use these portals to:

Blacklist Portal—Provide information about personal devices that are “blacklisted” and cannot be used to gain access to the network.

BYOD Portals—Enable employees to register their personal devices using native supplicant provisioning functionality.

Certificate Provisioning Portal—Enables administrators and employees to request for user/device certificate(s) for devices that cannot go through the BYOD flow.

Client Provisioning Portals—Force employees to download a posture agent on their devices that checks for compliance.

MDM Portals—Enable employees to enroll their mobile devices with an external Mobile Device Management (MDM) system.

My Devices Portals—Enable employees to add and register personal devices, including those that do not support native supplicant provisioning, and then manage them.

The answer is C.
 https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/ise/2-4/admin_guide/reorg/b_byod_2_4.html#:~:text=Employees%20do%20not%20access%20this,personal%20devices%20using%20native%20supplicants.
Native = BYOD , no native = My Devices

Selected Answer: C
registering personal devices, this is BYOD

Selected Answer: C
According to the Cisco Identity Services Engine Administrator Guide, the portal type that the engineer must configure for this scenario is - Bring Your Own Device portal.
The Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) portal allows employees to register their personal devices on the enterprise network using native supplicants. The portal also supports device onboarding using the internal CA for devices connected with Cisco switches and Cisco wireless LAN controllers.

questions.question_text: An engineer must configure web redirection for guests to a portal where no authentication is required and an Acceptable Use Policy must be accepted by the guest before network access is allowed. Which type of guest portal must be configured in Cisco ISE to meet the requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
To configure web redirection for guests to a portal where no authentication is required and an Acceptable Use Policy (AUP) must be accepted by the guest before network access is allowed, the correct answer is option - Hotspot. A hotspot guest portal is a simple web page that displays an AUP and requires the guest to click Accept in order to access the network. No guest account or credentials are needed for this type of portal.

questions.question_text: A network engineer is in the predeployment discovery phase of a Cisco ISE deployment and must discover the network. There is an existing NMS in the network. Which type of probe must be configured to gather the information?

discussion.content:
B is correct.
NMAP discover hosts and services on a network by sending packets and analyzing the response. The question is about network discovery and not querying a discovered hosts.

Selected Answer: A
To discover the network in the predeployment phase of a Cisco ISE deployment, the best type of probe to configure is option - SNMP. SNMP stands for Simple Network Management Protocol, which is a standard protocol for collecting and organizing information about network devices. SNMP can be used to query devices for their attributes, such as device type, vendor, model, operating system, IP address, MAC address, and so on. Cisco ISE supports two types of SNMP probes: SNMP Trap and SNMP Query. SNMP Trap probe listens for SNMP notifications sent by network devices, while SNMP Query probe actively polls network devices for information.

choices.D: Create an endpoint identity group for each department with the IP phone parent group.
choices.B: Create an endpoint identity group for each department with the profiled parent group.
choices.C: Add a tag for the endpoints of each department and add an endpoint to profiled group.
choices.A: Add a tag for the endpoints of each department and use the identity group filter.

questions.question_text:
An engineer must organize endpoints in a Cisco ISE identity management store to improve the operational management of IP phone endpoints. The endpoints must meet these requirements:
• classify endpoints for finance, sales, and marketing departments
• tag each endpoint as profiled

Which action organizes the endpoints?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Correct Answer is D.
By default the IP-Phone group has the "Profiled" groups as parent.

Profiled
 IP-Phones
 Sales
 Finance
 Marketing

Selected Answer: B
To organize endpoints in a Cisco ISE identity management store according to the given requirements, the correct answer is option - Create an endpoint identity group for each department with the profiled parent group. This option allows you to create custom groups for the finance, sales, and marketing departments, and to assign them as subgroups of the profiled group, which is a predefined group that contains all the endpoints that have been profiled by Cisco ISE .

questions.question_text: Which permission is common to the Active Directory Join and Leave operations?

choices.C: Set attributes on the Cisco ISE machine account.
choices.B: Search Active Directory to see if a Cisco ISE machine account already exists.
choices.A: Remove the Cisco ISE machine account from the domain.
choices.D: Create a Cisco ISE machine account in the domain if the machine account does not already exist.

discussion.content:
B correct
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/security/ise/2-3/ise_active_directory_integration/b_ISE_AD_integration_2x.html

tab -> Active Directory Account Permissions Required to Perform Various Operations

Selected Answer: B
Refer table: Active Directory Account Permissions Required to Perform Various Operations

https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/support/docs/security/identity-services-engine/217351-ad-integration-for-cisco-ise-gui-and-cli.html

tricky question:
but B is correct, it is what is common in both operations :
join:
The join operation requires the following account permissions:

 Search Active Directory (to see if a Cisco ISE machine account exists)

 Create Cisco ISE machine account to domain (if the machine account does not already exist)

 Set attributes on the new machine account (for example, Cisco ISE machine account password, SPN, dnsHostname)

leave :

The leave operation requires the following account permissions:

 Search Active Directory (to see if a Cisco ISE machine account exists)

 Remove the Cisco ISE machine account from the domain

If you perform a force leave (leave without the password), it will not remove the machine account from the domain. 


===============
as you can see the search is the only operation (or permission) that is common

Selected Answer: D
The correct answer is - Create a Cisco ISE machine account in the domain if the machine account does not already exist.

When joining a Cisco ISE appliance to an Active Directory domain, a machine account must be created for the appliance. This machine account is used by the appliance to authenticate to the domain and access resources. When leaving an Active Directory domain, the machine account must be removed.

The other options are not common to both the Join and Leave operations.

 Remove the Cisco ISE machine account from the domain: This is only required when leaving an Active Directory domain.
 Search Active Directory to see if a Cisco ISE machine account already exists: This can be done by any user with Read permission to the domain.
 Set attributes on the Cisco ISE machine account: This can be done by a user with Write permission to the domain.

Selected Answer: D
When joining a Cisco ISE appliance to an Active Directory domain, a machine account must be created for the appliance. This machine account is used by the appliance to authenticate to the domain and access resources. When leaving an Active Directory domain, the machine account must be removed.

The other options are not common to both the Join and Leave operations.

 Remove the Cisco ISE machine account from the domain: This is only required when leaving an Active Directory domain.
 Search Active Directory to see if a Cisco ISE machine account already exists: This can be done by any user with Read permission to the domain.
 Set attributes on the Cisco ISE machine account: This can be done by a user with Write permission to the domain.

Selected Answer: B
B is the best answer here

Selected Answer: B
The English is so bad!

The join operation requires the following account permissions:

Search Active Directory (to see if a Cisco ISE machine account exists)

Search is NOT a permission, its an action. I wish Cisco didn't outsource these exams!

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

The answer is B
